visits.text: Relax in Abano Terme, a town completely dedicated to spa culture where hundreds of hotels and facilities offer thermal treatments. The Romans were the first to bathe in these volcanic waters, and the tradition has continued unbroken for over two millennia.

Experience the therapeutic mud treatments, thermal pools, and steam grottos that have made this region Europe's largest thermal basin. The mineral-rich waters emerge at temperatures up to 87°C from deep underground sources.

activities.text: Explore the elegant spa town's gardens and promenades, where the wellness tradition blends with refined hospitality. The proximity to the Euganean Hills provides beautiful walking opportunities between treatments.

visits.text: Visit the Cathedral of San Lorenzo in Piazza Risorgimento, a 15th-century Gothic building that represents the religious heart of Alba. The three-nave interior, in gold and blue colors, elegantly contrasts with the exterior of red brick typical of Piedmontese architecture.

Admire the three medieval towers visible from Piazza Duomo: Torre Bonino, Torre Astesiano, and Torre Sineo, all dating from the 12th century. These stone sentinels bear witness to the turbulent past of a city frequently under attack and therefore heavily defended.

Discover Underground Alba with a fascinating guided tour led by an archaeologist through the city's underground spaces. From the ancient Roman temple to the theater, to the now-vanished medieval towers, an adventure through time to discover the oldest roots of this ancient city.

Explore the Church of the Maddalena on Via Vittorio Emanuele, a jewel of Piedmontese Baroque from the second half of the 18th century by Bernardo Antonio Vittone. The wooden portal on the façade is decorated with three crossed arrows, symbol of Blessed Margaret of Savoy.

activities.text: Immerse yourself in the gastronomic tradition of Alba, a UNESCO Creative City of Gastronomy since 2017. Taste the tajarin with butter and truffle, raviolini al plin, Alba-style raw beef, and the famous bonet, accompanied by local wines like Dolcetto d'Alba.

If you visit Alba in autumn, don't miss the International White Truffle Fair, an event that for over 90 years has celebrated the precious tuber of the Langhe with tastings, auctions, and shows in the world capital of truffles.

visits.text: Discover Arquà Petrarca, a beautiful stone village built on a hilltop overlooking the majestic Euganean Hills. This atmospheric settlement is famous as the place where the Herald of the Renaissance, Francesco Petrarca (Petrarch), spent his final years contemplating nature and composing poetry.

Visit Petrarch's House, preserved much as it was when the poet lived here in the 14th century. His tomb in the village square marks the final resting place of one of the founders of humanism and the Italian literary tradition.

activities.text: Wander the narrow stone lanes, enjoying the views that inspired Petrarch's contemplative verse. The village's unspoiled medieval character and poetic associations make it one of the most atmospheric destinations in the Euganean Hills.

visits.text: Experience Asolo, known as the 'City of a Hundred Horizons' and the 'Pearl of the Province of Treviso'. This picture-perfect town in the Dolomite foothills has attracted artists, writers, and royalty for centuries with its beauty and cultural richness.

Explore the historic center with its elegant palazzos, ancient castle, and stunning views across vine-covered hills. The atmospheric streets and squares reveal why this has been a haven for creative spirits throughout history.

activities.text: Soak in the countless horizons visible from various viewpoints around the town - each turn reveals new panoramas of hills, vineyards, and distant mountains that have inspired generations of artists and poets.

visits.text: Admire the Cathedral of Santa Maria Assunta in Piazza Risorgimento, an imposing 15th-century Gothic building that represents one of Asti's most important monuments. The three-nave interior, decorated in gold and blue colors, contrasts magnificently with the exterior of characteristic Piedmontese red brick.

Explore the medieval towers that dot the historic center, testimony to Asti's glorious past when it was a powerful city-state. Torre Troyana, Torre Comentina, and Torre Rossa are the most famous and offer evocative glimpses among the historic palaces of the center.

Visit the Palazzo Comunale in Piazza Risorgimento, which houses precious ancient frescoes from the Church of San Domenico, including a moving 14th-century Pietà and a panel depicting the Virgin and Child by Macrino d'Alba from 1501.

activities.text: Participate in a tasting of the wines that have made Asti famous worldwide: Asti Spumante DOCG and Barbera d'Asti. The area's wineries offer food and wine experiences that pair great wines with traditional Piedmontese cuisine.

If you're here in September, don't miss the Palio di Asti, one of Italy's oldest horse races held in central Piazza Alfieri. The event is preceded by a magnificent historical parade with over 1,200 participants in medieval costumes.

visits.text: Discover the Castle of Bardi, the largest and most famous fortress in the Parma province, dramatically positioned on a rocky spur overlooking the confluence of the Ceno and Noveglia rivers. This imposing stronghold, built in the 9th century and expanded over subsequent centuries, dominates the valley with its massive walls and towers, creating one of Italy's most spectacular castle panoramas.

Explore the castle's extensive interiors, which house museums dedicated to the medieval history of the region and the wildlife of the Apennines. The fortress walls stretch for hundreds of meters around the rocky outcrop, while the towers offer breathtaking views over the mountain valleys stretching toward the distant peaks.

activities.text: Wander through the medieval village of Bardi clustered at the foot of the castle, where traditional mountain architecture and ancient churches tell the story of centuries of Apennine community life. The dramatic setting and historical importance make Bardi the essential destination for understanding the feudal history of the Parma mountains.

visits.text: Explore the Castello Falletti di Barolo, a majestic 13th-century fortress overlooking the village that now houses WiMu - the Wine Museum. This multimedia and sensory journey will immerse you in the peasant world of wine, descending room after room through the seasons of the vine, harvest sounds, and cellar stories.

Visit the Regional Enoteca of Barolo inside the castle, where you can taste over one hundred labels to understand the styles, vintages, and crus of what is considered the king of Italian wines. An unmissable experience for wine enthusiasts.

Discover the curious Corkscrew Museum in Piazza Mazzocchi, a small but fascinating collection of over 500 corkscrews from the 18th century to today that tells the story of the ritual of opening bottles through the centuries.
Discovery of the village of Barolo, its castle housing the wine museum and hills covered with Nebbiolo vineyards.

activities.text: Wander through the vineyards surrounding the village, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2014 as part of the Vineyard Landscape of Piedmont. The rolling hills covered with rows of Nebbiolo offer unforgettable photographic views, especially during the golden hours of sunset.

Reach the Cappella del Barolo in the Brunate vineyards, just minutes from Barolo. This small deconsecrated church, transformed into a contemporary artwork by artists Sol LeWitt and David Tremlett in 1999, has become one of the most photographed symbols of the Langhe.

days_plan.itin_title: Piedmont Wine & Truffle Road Trip: Turin, Alba & Barolo in 9 Days
Piedmont's Hidden Villages: Langhe, Monferrato & The Alps

visits.text: Discover Bassano del Grappa, a picturesque city on the crystal-clear Brenta River with the Venetian Prealps as a dramatic backdrop. Founded in pre-Roman times, the city preserves medieval and Venetian architecture including a castle, fortified walls, cobbled piazzas, and buildings with faded frescoes and winged lions.

Cross the iconic Ponte degli Alpini, a wooden covered bridge spanning the Brenta since the Middle Ages. Andrea Palladio designed the current structure in 1569, and it has been faithfully rebuilt following his plans after each destruction - most recently in 1945.

Visit the Civic Museum housed in the convent of St. Francis, featuring archaeological collections, medieval art, works by Canova and Tiepolo, and a room dedicated to local painter Jacopo dal Ponte (Jacopo da Bassano). The adjacent church contains a remarkable 14th-century crucifix.
Explore the Poli Grappa Museum to learn about grappa - the potent Italian grape-based spirit for which Bassano is famous. Watch the distillation process and sample the local specialty.

activities.text: Wander the historic center admiring Palazzo del Municipio (1404) with its gorgeous frescoed loggia, Palazzo Michieli-Bonato with façade frescoes by Jacopo da Bassano, and the Duomo originally built in the year 1000.
Browse the artisan ceramics shops selling imaginative hand-painted cups, bowls, plates, and terrines. The city comes alive during festivals with parades, entertainment, and authentic local spirit.

days_plan.itin_title: Veneto's Palladian Villas: Day Trips from Padova to Brenta Canal & Lakes

visits.text: Explore Punta Spartivento, the panoramic point where Lake Como divides into two branches creating its characteristic Y shape. From this legendary promontory you can admire a breathtaking view immortalised by Alessandro Manzoni in The Betrothed, with the mountains reflected in the crystal-clear waters.

Visit the Church of San Giacomo, a gem of Romanesque-Lombard art built in the twelfth century using the characteristic grey stone of Moltrasio. Inside you can admire precious frescoes and sculptures from different historical periods, while the bell tower bears witness to the village's ancient defensive system.

Wander through the grounds of Villa Serbelloni, a magnificent garden of nearly 21 hectares stretching across a steep promontory. This historic residence, now owned by the Rockefeller Foundation, boasts 18 km of paths among rare plants and panoramic vistas that have enchanted distinguished guests over the centuries, including Leonardo da Vinci and Alessandro Manzoni.

Discover the Gardens of Villa Melzi d'Eril, a botanical paradise on the western lakefront created in the early nineteenth century by the noble Milanese family. Among exotic plants, ancient trees, antique statues and archaeological finds, you can admire the famous statue of Dante and Beatrice that inspired Franz Liszt to compose his Dante Sonata.
Discovery of the cobblestone streets and staircases in the center of Bellagio, the pearl of Lake Como
Walk through the villa gardens and viewpoints around Bellagio

activities.text: Walk up the Salita Serbelloni, a picturesque stairway connecting the lakefront to the old town through boutiques and characteristic establishments. Once known as Il Fossato for its medieval defensive role, it now features a commemorative plaque to the composer Franz Liszt, who stayed at length in this enchanting village.
Boat crossing between Bellagio and the neighboring villages of Lake Como

visits.text: Ride the funicular up to Città Alta, one of Italy's best-preserved medieval villages enclosed within the majestic Venetian Walls, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Wandering through the cobbled streets you'll discover centuries of history and Renaissance art in a timeless atmosphere that has captivated travellers of every era.

Admire Piazza Vecchia, the true civic drawing room overlooked by the Palazzo della Ragione, the Civic Tower (Campanone) and the Angelo Mai Library. Every evening the Campanone bell tolls one hundred times, just as in Venetian times when it signalled the closing of the city gates, evoking an atmosphere steeped in historical charm.

Visit the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore with its richly Baroque interiors adorned with tapestries and gilded stuccowork, and the adjacent Cappella Colleoni, a Renaissance masterpiece built as a mausoleum for the condottiere Bartolomeo Colleoni. The chapel's polychrome marble façades rank among the finest in Italy.

Explore the Accademia Carrara, one of Italy's most prestigious art galleries with over 1,800 paintings by artists such as Botticelli, Raphael, Mantegna, Titian and Canaletto. Directly opposite stands the GAMeC, the Gallery of Modern and Contemporary Art, creating a unique dialogue between tradition and modernity.

activities.text: Ride even higher on the San Vigilio Funicular to the Castle, crossing breathtaking landscapes with spectacular views of the city rooftops, medieval towers and the Lombard plain. From the castle ramparts you can enjoy one of the most beautiful sunsets in Lombardy.

Lose yourself in the Lorenzo Rota Botanical Garden, a small urban Eden of 2,400 sq m on the panoramic terraces of Città Alta. From here you can admire a spectacular view of the city and surrounding mountains, with the Venetian Walls seeming to merge with the landscape in perfect harmony.

visits.text: Explore the Museo di Santa Giulia, an extraordinary monastic complex and the city's main museum housing treasures of exceptional historical and artistic importance. From the ninth-century Cross of Desiderius to the incredible frescoes of the Nuns' Choir, from the remains of ancient Roman Domus houses to the marvellous interiors of the Basilica of San Salvatore, it is part of the UNESCO site in the heart of Brescia.

Admire the Roman Archaeological Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site comprising Piazza del Foro, the Capitolium with the hall dedicated to the Winged Victory, the Republican Sanctuary, the ancient theatre and the Roman Basilica. This extraordinary complex bears witness to the greatness of Brixia, one of northern Italy's most important cities in the Roman era.

Visit Piazza Loggia, the beating heart of Brescia characterised by a splendid blend of styles with a clear Venetian imprint. The Palazzo della Loggia, built between 1492 and 1570 with contributions from Palladio and Sansovino, dominates the square alongside the Clock Tower with its ancient astronomical clock.

Discover the Pinacoteca Tosio Martinengo, one of northern Italy's most important galleries with works by Raphael, Foppa, Moretto, Romanino, Lotto, Ceruti and Hayez. The route through 21 exhibition halls offers an intense journey from late Gothic to the early nineteenth century through the great Brescian Renaissance painting.

Discover Brescia, a hidden gem whose 3,200 years of history offer one of Northern Italy's richest archaeological and artistic heritages. The monumental Roman Forum area preserves the best-preserved Roman public buildings in Northern Italy, a UNESCO World Heritage treasure.

Explore the huge Brescia Castle (the Falcon of Italy) with its battlements, tower, drawbridge, and Arms Museum in the keep. The steep Cidneo hill offers unparalleled views over the city and surrounding plains to the distant Alps.

Visit the Monastic Complex of San Salvatore/Santa Giulia (Santa Giulia City Museum), housing 11,000 works of art and archaeological finds spanning 3,000 years. The museum itself occupies a remarkable series of historic buildings including Lombard-era basilicas.

Admire the spacious squares lined with stunning buildings, including the Art Deco Piazza della Vittoria (with the Torrione - Italy's first skyscraper) and the Renaissance Piazza della Loggia with its beautiful astronomical clock.

activities.text: Climb to Brescia Castle on the Colle Cidneo, a great fortress built between the fourteenth and sixteenth centuries in a commanding position over the city. A favourite destination for relaxing walks in the greenery, it houses the Luigi Marzoli Arms Museum and offers breathtaking views of the city and the Bergamo valleys.

Stroll through Piazza Paolo VI admiring the Duomo Vecchio, a rare example of Romanesque architecture with a circular plan, and the Duomo Nuovo completed in 1825. Then lose yourself in the ancient Carmine quarter with its evocative lanes, traditional taverns and bohemian atmosphere.

Explore the Duomo Vecchio (Old Cathedral), a rare circular Romanesque structure, alongside the Duomo Nuovo. The Teatro Grande opera house offers a glimpse into the refined cultural life of this prosperous city.
Try the local Bagoss cheese, produced in small quantities in the nearby village of Bagolino, with its distinctive dense, salty flavor enhanced by hints of walnuts and chestnuts.

visits.text: Admire the Cathedral of Sant'Evasio, consecrated in 1107, with its grand and rare Narthex that represents a masterpiece of architectural engineering. Inside you can admire a precious 13th-century wooden Crucifix and visit the Cathedral Treasure Museum in the Open Sacristy.

Visit the Jewish Complex, one of the most important in Italy, with the extraordinary Baroque Synagogue built in 1595. The interior decorations of surprising richness testify to the prosperity of the Jewish community of Casale. The complex also includes the Silver Museum and the Museum of Lights.

Explore the Civic Museum and Bistolfi Plaster Cast Gallery, which in addition to the Picture Gallery houses works by Symbolist sculptor Leonardo Bistolfi and an exhibition dedicated to Carlo Vidua, the traveling count who explored the Far East from the 19th century.

Discover the Castle of Monferrato in central Piazza Castello, today home to the Tourist Office, the Regional Enoteca of Monferrato, and cultural events. An unmissable visit to discover the wines and typical products of the territory.

activities.text: Taste the Krumiri Rossi, the symbolic biscuits of Casale Monferrato whose recipe dates back to 1878 by pastry chef Domenico Rossi. This tradition has been carried on since 1953 by the Portinaro Family, guardians of the secret of these unique sweets.

Reach the Sacro Monte di Crea, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in a splendid panoramic position. This devotional complex includes the Sanctuary, 23 chapels, and 5 hermitages built between 1589 and 1612 in a place of ancient Marian worship.

visits.text: Discover Castelfranco Veneto, birthplace of the renowned painter Giorgione and a gorgeous town with an almost intact medieval defensive wall. The substantial brick walls encircle a perfectly preserved historic center filled with architectural treasures.

Visit the Cathedral to see Giorgione's Madonna, the masterpiece Castelfranco Madonna that draws art lovers from around the world. This revolutionary work exemplifies the Venetian High Renaissance style Giorgione pioneered.

activities.text: Walk the walls and explore the charming center, perhaps timing your visit for one of the town's festivals including the popular chocolate fair. The medieval atmosphere provides excellent settings for photography.

days_plan.itin_title: Veneto's Palladian Villas: Day Trips from Padova to Brenta Canal & Lakes

visits.text: Explore the Rocca Viscontea, an imposing medieval fortress built between 1342 and 1349 at the behest of Luchino Visconti of Milan. With its four square corner towers, double defensive walls, and deep moat, it represents one of the best-preserved castles in Italy. Today it houses a fascinating Museum of Medieval Life.

Admire the Palazzo del Podestà in Piazza del Borgo, emblem of civic power built at the end of the 13th century by Alberto Scotti, lord of Piacenza. The elegant exposed brick façade dominates the village's main square, creating one of the most photographed medieval views in Emilia Romagna.

Visit the Collegiate Church of Santa Maria, a place of worship with ancient origins dating back to the 7th century. The sober Romanesque gabled façade decorated with blind arches hides naves adorned with precious 15th-century frescoes of extraordinary beauty.

Discover the Geological Museum housed in the ancient Hospital of Santo Spirito, a 13th-century building that once offered hospitality to pilgrims on the Via Francigena. The paleontological collections bear witness to millions of years of natural history in the Piacenza territory.

Discover Castell'Arquato, one of Italy's most beautiful medieval villages perched on a hilltop overlooking the Val d'Arda. The remarkably preserved historic center dates from the 14th to 16th centuries, featuring the imposing Rocca Viscontea fortress, the Romanesque Collegiata church, and the elegant Palazzo del Podestà that together create an authentic medieval atmosphere.

Explore the Rocca Viscontea, a mighty fortress built in 1342 by Luchino Visconti that dominates the village. The castle's towers offer panoramic views over the surrounding hills covered with vineyards producing the local Colli Piacentini wines, while the medieval streets below retain their original character.

activities.text: Stroll through the Garden of Poetry, a large green expanse where you can find a silent refuge among evergreen trees and romantic benches. From here you can admire the entire Val d'Arda and several monuments dedicated to illustrious figures such as the luthier Antonio Stradivari.

Lose yourself in the cobblestone lanes of the village, one of the best-preserved windows onto medieval life in Italy, framed by noble palaces and Romanesque churches expressing the power of the Scotti, Visconti, and Sforza families.

Walk through the entrance gates into the historic center, where time seems to have stopped in the Middle Ages. The village has served as a filming location for numerous historical movies thanks to its remarkably intact medieval architecture and atmospheric cobblestone streets.

visits.text: Discover Chioggia, like an unspoiled Venice with a slow, gentle pace of life on the southern tip of the Venetian Lagoon. Older than Venice itself, this fishing town is crisscrossed by canals and bridges, retaining the authentic character that the more famous city has lost to tourism.

Visit the Clock Tower Museum housing the oldest working clock in the world, a remarkable medieval timepiece that has measured the hours for over seven centuries. The tower offers views over the town's atmospheric waterways and fishing boats.

Explore Sottomarina, Chioggia's lively beachside suburb featuring a remarkable 10-kilometer-long sandy beach up to 300 meters wide. The sand, rich in minerals including augite and quartz, is renowned for therapeutic sand bathing treatments.

activities.text: Take a boat trip around Chioggia to experience the lagoon landscapes and traditional fishing culture. Watch the daily rhythms of one of Italy's oldest and largest fishing ports, where the wholesale and retail fish markets overflow with the morning's fresh catch.

If visiting in June, experience the Palio della Marciliana, a historic reenactment when hundreds of people in 14th-century costumes transform the town with noble ladies, knights, musicians, games, and parades.

visits.text: Experience Cittadella, home to Europe's best medieval parapet walkway. Here you can circumnavigate the entire town by walking atop its medieval defensive walls - a unique opportunity to understand medieval fortification from the defender's perspective.

Explore the historic center enclosed within the complete circuit of walls, where medieval character has been remarkably preserved. The churches, palazzos, and piazzas within create an authentic atmosphere.

activities.text: In September, don't miss the town-wide medieval fair when historical costumes, crafts, and entertainment transform Cittadella into a living museum of medieval life. In winter, a charming ice rink appears in the central square.

visits.text: Visit the Reggia di Colorno, often called the 'Little Versailles of Parma' for its grand French-inspired architecture. This magnificent ducal palace was transformed in the 18th century by the Bourbon rulers into an elegant residence featuring sumptuous state rooms, frescoed ceilings, and richly decorated apartments that rival the great royal palaces of Europe.

Explore the extensive Ducal Gardens surrounding the palace, designed in the formal French style with geometric parterres, fountains, and tree-lined avenues. The gardens offer a peaceful retreat where centuries of horticultural artistry create a harmonious landscape perfect for contemplative walks.

activities.text: Discover the palace's role in regional history as a residence for the Farnese and Bourbon dynasties. The town of Colorno itself, easily accessible by public transport from Parma, offers charming streets and the authentic atmosphere of a historic Emilian settlement.

visits.text: Admire the Como Cathedral, a splendid church blending Gothic and Renaissance elements in the heart of the city. Built from 1396 and completed in the eighteenth century with the majestic dome designed by Filippo Juvarra, it is one of Lombardy's most important religious monuments. The richly decorated façade and solemn interiors bear witness to centuries of devotion and art.

Visit the Tempio Voltiano, an elegant Neoclassical museum dedicated to Alessandro Volta, Como's illustrious citizen and inventor of the electric battery. Set on the lakefront in a panoramic position, the museum houses original scientific instruments and documents tracing the revolutionary discoveries of the scientist who changed the course of history.

Ride the funicular up to Brunate, the balcony of the Alps offering breathtaking panoramas of the lake and the Alpine chain. This charming village at 720 metres altitude is reachable in just 7 minutes of scenic travel and rewards visitors with unforgettable views, particularly captivating at sunset.

visits.text: Visit the Castle of Compiano, a fortress worthy of note for its significant role in the history of the region. Perched high in the Apennine mountains, this medieval stronghold controlled important routes through the mountains, and its well-preserved structure offers insight into military architecture adapted to the challenging mountain terrain.

Explore the tiny village of Compiano, one of the most remote and atmospheric settlements in the Parma Apennines. The isolation has preserved its medieval character, with stone houses clinging to the mountainside beneath the protective walls of the castle above.

activities.text: Enjoy the panoramic mountain views from the castle's elevated position, where the Apennine peaks and forested valleys create a dramatic natural backdrop. The journey to Compiano itself winds through spectacular mountain scenery, making the drive an integral part of the experience.

visits.text: Begin exploring Prosecco Country at Conegliano, the gateway to 170 kilometers of winding roads through charming villages and vine-draped hillsides. The unique microclimate of these UNESCO-listed slopes produces Italy's most celebrated sparkling wine.
Visit the historic center of Conegliano with its castle, medieval streets, and Renaissance architecture. The old town's atmosphere reflects centuries as a prosperous wine-trading center.

activities.text: Sample prosecco at local wineries and cellars, discovering the differences between DOC and DOCG designations. The rolling hills between here and Valdobbiadene offer some of Italy's most beautiful wine country landscapes.

visits.text: Explore the Delta del Po Regional Park, where Italy's longest river meets the Adriatic Sea in a landscape of extraordinary natural beauty. This vast wetland ecosystem is home to over 400 bird species including flocks of wild pink flamingoes that create spectacular displays against the marshy backdrop.

Visit the Giardino Botanico Litoraneo di Porto Caleri, a coastal botanical garden offering walks through lush vegetation at the edge of the sea. The diverse habitats - from dunes to pine forests to marshlands - support unique plant and animal communities.

activities.text: Discover wild beaches, island resorts, and the unique landscape where freshwater and saltwater ecosystems merge. The area offers exceptional opportunities for cycling, birdwatching, and boat excursions through the labyrinthine waterways.

days_plan.itin_title: Veneto's Palladian Villas: Day Trips from Padova to Brenta Canal & Lakes

visits.text: Explore the Castle of Desenzano del Garda, an imposing fortress erected in the early Middle Ages probably on the remains of an ancient Roman castrum. Of the original construction, portions of walls and truncated corner towers survive; from the panoramic observatory at the top you can enjoy a spectacular view of Lake Garda that amply rewards the climb.

Visit the Cathedral of Santa Maria Maddalena, a splendid example of late Brescian Renaissance built between the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries. Inside it houses important works by Andrea Celesti, and in the Chapel of the Blessed Sacrament you can admire G.B. Tiepolo's celebrated Last Supper from 1738, a masterpiece of eighteenth-century Venetian painting.

Discover the Roman Villa, the most important testimony to the great late-antique villas of northern Italy. Built between the first and fourth centuries AD and accidentally discovered in 1921, it preserves over 240 sq m of extraordinary polychrome mosaics featuring cupids, maenads, satyrs and wild animals, bearing witness to the refinement of Roman life on the lake.

Admire the Giovanni Rambotti Archaeological Museum, rich in prehistoric finds from the Lake Garda area dating mainly from the Bronze Age. Among the treasures it houses is what is considered the oldest wooden plough in the world, a precious testimony to the first farming communities that inhabited these shores.

Explore Desenzano del Garda, the largest town on Lake Garda with a vibrant waterfront, historic center, and excellent transport connections. The Archaeological Museum houses remarkable Roman mosaics from a 4th-century villa, showcasing the sophisticated lifestyle of ancient inhabitants.
Discover the castle overlooking the lake, now used for open-air opera performances each summer. The Torre di San Martino and old villas add historical depth to this animated resort town.

activities.text: Stroll through the picturesque Porto Vecchio, one of Desenzano's most evocative corners overlooked by the broad arcades of Palazzo Todeschini. The dock took shape in the days of the Venetian Republic; don't miss the curious Stone of the Unemployed from 1555, where town criers and those condemned for bankruptcy would stand.

Stroll the animated waterfront promenade lined with cafés and gelaterias, watching the boats come and go in the bustling harbor. The weekly markets and seasonal events bring local color to this year-round destination.

visits.text: Explore Este, a 3,000-year-old walled town that gave its name to the powerful Este dynasty who later ruled Ferrara. The Archaeological Museum houses remarkable pre-Roman artifacts from the ancient Venetic civilization, including the famous Situla Benvenuti bronze bucket with detailed figural scenes.

Walk through the walled park where Este's medieval castle once stood, now a peaceful garden enclosed by battlemented walls and towers. The romantic ruins and ancient trees create an atmospheric setting for exploration.
Discover the town's thriving ceramics industry, a tradition dating back centuries, with artisan workshops producing distinctive hand-painted majolica in the local style.

activities.text: Combine your visit with the nearby Arquà Petrarca (18 minutes by bus) or Monselice (8 minutes by train) to explore multiple Euganean Hills gems in a single day.

visits.text: Discover Feltre, a charming town huddled on a small hill and picturesquely surrounded by the powerful peaks of the Dolomites. Tall stone houses with frescoed façades and whimsical chimneys capture the imagination, while the stunning main square - Piazza Maggiore - anchors the historic center.
Explore the museums, churches, lovely theatre, and medieval streets that give Feltre its distinctive character. The blend of Venetian elegance and Alpine setting creates a unique atmosphere.

activities.text: If you have a car, venture to the nearby 11th-century Sanctuary of St. St. Vittore and Corona, a remarkable Romanesque church in a peaceful rural setting with important early frescoes.

visits.text: Visit Follina, one of Italy's most beautiful villages, centered around a magnificent medieval abbey. The Cistercian Abbey of Santa Maria dates to the 12th century, its Romanesque-Gothic cloister remaining remarkably preserved as a place of profound spiritual atmosphere.

Explore nearby Cison di Valmarino, another officially designated beautiful village dominated by Castel Brando - one of Italy's largest castles, now functioning as a luxury hotel. The village streets retain their medieval character.

Discover the village of Mel if time permits, completing a trio of the most beautiful villages in the Veneto's northern hills. The surrounding vineyards and hills create a peaceful countryside setting.

visits.text: Explore the Castle of Fontanellato, a perfectly preserved medieval fortress surrounded by a wide moat filled with water. This 14th-century stronghold houses an exquisite chamber decorated with frescoes by Parmigianino depicting the myth of Diana and Actaeon, considered one of the finest examples of Mannerist painting in Italy.

Visit the Labirinto della Masone, the world's largest green labyrinth covering over eight hectares with bamboo plants reaching heights of fifteen meters. Created by art collector Franco Maria Ricci, this extraordinary maze also houses a museum of art, a publishing archive, and offers panoramic views from the rooftop terrace over the intricate pathways below.

activities.text: Wander through the charming historic center of Fontanellato, where medieval porticoes line the main square surrounding the castle. The town has maintained its authentic character, with traditional shops and the peaceful atmosphere of a fortified village unchanged for centuries.

visits.text: Explore the Castle and Historic Park of Grazzano Visconti, the most precious part of this unique village. The 14th-century castle, completely restored by Giuseppe Visconti di Modrone in eclectic style, offers guided tours through the courtyard, the richly furnished reception rooms, and the bedrooms on the first floor.

Wander through the Castle Park, 15 hectares of English and Italian gardens designed by Giuseppe Visconti. Statues, vases, columns, fountains, and an extraordinary variety of trees and shrubs create a fairytale atmosphere, completed by the delightful little girls' cottage that seems straight out of a storybook.

Visit the Wax Museum with statues of figures connected to Piacenza's history, and the Torture Museum in the Palazzetto dell'Istituzione, small but complete, with torture instruments accompanied by explanatory panels. Adjacent is an Escape Room themed around the Inquisition.

Admire the Parish Church of Saints Cosmas and Damian, the oldest building in the village with 17th-century renovations. Inside, the Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes houses numerous ex-votos, testimony to popular devotion through the centuries.

activities.text: Lose yourself in the white lanes of the village, admiring the cottages with frescoed façades, the arcades, and the statues. In the Cortevecchia you'll find the statue of Aloisa, the famous ghost of Grazzano Visconti, and a small museum of agricultural tools under the long portico.

Explore the numerous craft shops and souvenir stores, open in every season on weekends. This rare example of revivalist architecture, recognized as a City of Art by the Emilia Romagna Region in 1986, will make you feel catapulted back in time 700 years.

visits.text: Discover the Grotte di Caglieron, where wooden walkways lead through a series of caves with countless waterfalls streaming down rocky gorge sides. This area of extraordinary natural beauty combines geological wonders with human history stretching back centuries.

Explore the unique cheese caves where a local dairy company matures cheese in the natural cool humidity. You can purchase slabs of this cave-aged cheese, adding a delicious souvenir to your nature adventure.

activities.text: Hike the trails through this remarkable gorge where water, rock, and time have created a magical landscape. The combination of natural caves and quarried grottos offers insights into both geological and human history.

visits.text: Admire the viewpoint at Piazza Castello, the most famous panoramic terrace in the Langhe offering a 360-degree view over vineyards dotted with villages and castles. On clear days, the gaze extends to the Alps, offering one of Piedmont's most breathtaking natural spectacles.

Climb the 31-meter-high Bell Tower, built in 1710, to enjoy an even wider view of the surrounding hills. Near the viewpoint stands the monument to the winegrower, a bronze statue paying tribute to those who work the vines and produce Barolo.

Visit the Church of San Martino, an elegant Baroque building with a brick façade and interiors decorated with precious frescoes. It's one of the most representative churches in the area and houses artworks of great value.

activities.text: Seek out the giant benches of the Big Bench Community Project scattered around La Morra. These colorful installations, created to enhance the landscape of the Langhe, allow you to enjoy spectacular views of the vineyard-covered hills from an unusual and fun perspective.

Join a tasting at the historic cellars of La Morra, one of the most important areas for Barolo DOCG production. Cantina Mascarello, Cantina Marcarini, and Cantina Oddero offer guided tours with tastings and vineyard walks.

visits.text: Explore the Park of the Hundred Lakes (Parco dei Cento Laghi), a stunning natural area in the Parma Apennines featuring dozens of glacial lakes scattered across the mountain landscape. Lago Santo Parmense, the largest and most accessible, sits at over 1,500 meters altitude surrounded by forests and peaks, offering a refreshing mountain escape especially welcome on hot summer days.

Hike through the alpine-like scenery where crystal-clear lakes mirror the surrounding peaks and forests. The park encompasses some of the highest terrain in the Parma province, with trails leading to panoramic viewpoints on Mount Aquilotto and other summits offering sweeping vistas over the lake-dotted landscape.

activities.text: Discover the diverse mountain flora and fauna protected within the park boundaries. The area offers exceptional hiking opportunities ranging from gentle lakeside walks to challenging peak ascents, all set within landscapes that feel far removed from the plains of Emilia-Romagna below.

visits.text: Conclude your grand tour at Lake Fimon, the oldest lake in Northern Italy at 35,000 years of age - predating even Lake Garda. This tranquil natural setting offers a peaceful escape for walking, picnicking, or simply contemplating the landscape.

Explore the shores and surrounding Berici Hills, where nature and agriculture create a pastoral landscape within easy reach of Vicenza. The lake's ancient origins add geological interest to its natural beauty.

activities.text: Enjoy a leisurely walk around the lake, perhaps with a picnic. The peaceful atmosphere provides a perfect finale to your exploration of the Veneto's extraordinary diversity of cultural and natural treasures.

visits.text: Visit the prepositural Church of Saints Philip and James, known as the old church, a religious building dating from 1315 that is the historic spiritual heart of Laveno. Beside it stands the Church of Sant'Ambrogio, built in 1940 by architect Paolo Mezzanotte in a modern style, together forming the sacred heritage of this charming lakeside town.

Discover Villa De Angeli Frua, an elegant eighteenth-century residence donated to the municipality and now home to the public library. The magnificent Parco delle Terrazze surrounding it offers breathtaking views of Lake Maggiore, with an evocative entrance tunnel that in spring is draped in blooming wisteria, creating a fairy-tale setting.

Ride the cable car up to Poggio Sant'Elsa for a privileged perspective of Lake Maggiore. This panoramic excursion offers spectacular views of the blue lake waters, the Borromean Islands in the distance and the Alpine skyline, delivering an unforgettable experience for nature and photography lovers.

activities.text: Stroll along the Laveno lakefront, one of Lake Maggiore's most evocative promenades offering views of the town, Stresa on the opposite shore and the famous Borromean Islands. From here ferries depart for Verbania, giving you the chance to explore both sides of the lake.

visits.text: Stroll through Lazise, whose Scaliger Castle (not open for visits) and defensive walls create a picturesque medieval ensemble on Lake Garda's shores. The atmospheric lakefront promenade offers views across the water to the distant mountains, perfect for a relaxing evening passeggiata.

Visit the Church of San Nicolò, an ancient Romanesque church within the castle walls featuring medieval frescoes. The intimate scale and historic atmosphere capture the authentic character of a traditional lakeside community.

activities.text: Enjoy the beautiful lakeside setting, perhaps with a gelato from one of the local shops. The colorful boats bobbing in the harbor and the castle silhouette create postcard-perfect views at every turn.

visits.text: Admire the Palazzo Verbania, an Art Nouveau architectural jewel built in the nineteenth century that regularly hosts art exhibitions and cultural events. This elegant historic building is the cultural heart of the town, bearing witness to the period of great prosperity Luino enjoyed as a major trading centre on Lake Maggiore.

Visit the Church of San Pietro, one of the most significant religious buildings in the old town preserving precious artistic testimonies of local devotion. Together with the Church of San Giuseppe, it forms the sacred heritage of this fascinating lakeside town.

Don't miss the famous Luino Market, one of the largest open-air markets in the area and among the oldest in Europe. Every Wednesday the town centre streets come alive with stalls offering local produce, handicrafts and gastronomic specialities, attracting visitors from across the region and nearby Switzerland.

activities.text: Stroll along the magnificent Luino lakefront, one of Lake Maggiore's most beautiful promenades winding between elegant historic buildings and lush green spaces. The view over the crystal-clear waters and surrounding mountains invites moments of pure relaxation and contemplation.

Venture onto the panoramic trails around Luino, such as the walk to Colmegna along the lake or the hike to Monte Bedea and the charming Laghetto di Moncucco, immersed in Alpine scenery of extraordinary beauty.

visits.text: Stroll along the Menaggio lakefront, an elegant Belle Époque promenade lined with refined cafés and Art Nouveau palms. This golden ribbon facing the waters of the Lario offers picturesque views of historic villas such as Villa Mylius Vigoni and Villa Govone, with the majestic Alps as a natural backdrop.

Explore the old town of Menaggio, characterised by cobbled lanes and lively little squares where you can breathe an atmosphere of times gone by. The bell tower with its copper dome dominates the village, while the pastel-coloured façades of the traditional houses create an environment of rare lakeside elegance.

Let yourself be enchanted by the majestic Milan Cathedral, a masterpiece of Gothic architecture that dominates the square of the same name. With its 3,500 statues, soaring spires reaching towards the sky and the famous gilded Madonnina standing 4 metres tall, this cathedral dedicated to Santa Maria Nascente is the beating heart of the city. Climb to the terraces for a spectacular view over the metropolis and the Alps on clear days.

Walk through the splendid Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, Milan's refined drawing room inaugurated in 1867. This elegant covered passage with its majestic iron and glass dome connects Piazza Duomo to Piazza della Scala, offering a unique experience among prestigious boutiques, historic cafés and exquisite mosaics. The architecture designed by Giuseppe Mengoni is a symbol of nineteenth-century Milanese ambition.

Explore the Museo del Novecento in the Palazzo dell'Arengario, a treasure trove of over 400 masterpieces of twentieth-century Italian art. From the celebrated Quarto Stato by Pellizza da Volpedo to works by Boccioni, Modigliani and Fontana, the chronological route guides you through Futurism, Metaphysical Art and Conceptual Art. The hall dedicated to Lucio Fontana offers a breathtaking view of the Duomo through the large windows.

Admire Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper, one of the most famous paintings in the world housed in the refectory of Santa Maria delle Grazie. Created between 1494 and 1498 using an innovative technique, this depiction of the Last Supper reveals Leonardo's genius in its dramatic composition and the psychological depth of the figures. A deeply moving experience that requires advance booking.

Discover the Pinacoteca di Brera, one of Italy's most prestigious museums founded in 1776. The collection includes absolute masterpieces such as Caravaggio's Supper at Emmaus, Mantegna's Dead Christ, Piero della Francesca's Brera Altarpiece and Raphael's Marriage of the Virgin. Hayez's celebrated Kiss is the icon of Italian Romanticism.

Immerse yourself in the atmosphere of the Church of San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore, known as Milan's Sistine Chapel. The vivid frescoes extend across no fewer than 4,000 square metres and are the work of the greatest masters of sixteenth-century Lombard painting, including Bernardino Luini. The plain façade on Corso Magenta conceals an interior of astonishing beauty.
Discovery of the Duomo di Milano and climb to the rooftops to admire the panoramic view of the city

Stroll along the romantic Navigli, the ancient canal system designed in part by Leonardo da Vinci to connect Milan to the lakes and the sea. The recently renovated Darsena offers picturesque views, artisan workshops and a uniquely bohemian atmosphere in the heart of the city.

Explore the Castello Sforzesco, one of Europe's largest fortresses housing priceless treasures including Michelangelo's Pietà Rondanini and Leonardo's frescoes. Behind it stretches the Parco Sempione, the city's green lung and the perfect setting for a relaxing walk to the Arch of Peace.

visits.text: Discover Villa Foscari La Malcontenta, another stunning Palladian masterpiece rising elegantly from the banks of the Brenta Canal. This 16th-century villa showcases Andrea Palladio's genius for proportion and harmony, with breathtaking interior frescoes that rank among the finest examples of Venetian villa decoration.

Explore the Brenta Riviera, the historic waterway connecting Padua to Venice that was once lined with over 70 noble villas. The canal served as the summer escape route for Venetian aristocracy, who would travel by burchiello (traditional boat) to their countryside retreats.

activities.text: Consider a scenic boat cruise along the Brenta Canal, following the historic route that Venetian nobles traveled for centuries. The journey passes multiple villas and offers a unique perspective on this remarkable concentration of architectural heritage.

visits.text: Visit Monselice Castle, housing one of the finest collections of medieval arms and armor in the Veneto, second only to the Doge's Palace in Venice. The castle's remarkable fireplaces are themselves works of art, showcasing the refined craftsmanship of medieval artisans.

Climb the Seven Churches Sanctuary (Santuario delle Sette Chiese), a pilgrimage route of seven chapels ascending the hillside that once granted the same indulgences as visiting Rome's seven pilgrimage churches. The Via Sacra offers beautiful views of the surrounding hills.
Explore the Old Cathedral and the elegant Villa Duodo, designed by Vincenzo Scamozzi, surrounded by gardens and offering panoramic views from its hillside position.

activities.text: Walk the fortified historic center, where medieval walls, towers, and gates create an authentic atmosphere. The town's strategic hilltop position made it an important defensive stronghold for centuries.

visits.text: Discover Montagnana, renowned for producing some of Italy's finest prosciutto and encircled by one of Europe's best-preserved medieval defensive walls. The nearly complete circuit of walls, punctuated by 24 towers, creates a dramatic silhouette visible for miles across the Veneto plain.

Explore the castle, the elegant main square, and the stunning Cathedral with its notable works of art. The town center retains its medieval character within the protective embrace of the mighty fortifications.

activities.text: Experience the annual Prosciutto Festival celebrating the local cured ham tradition. The town's Prosciutto Veneto Berico-Euganeo DOP is produced following centuries-old methods in the unique microclimate of the Euganean Hills.

visits.text: Stroll through the medieval historic center of Neive, one of the Most Beautiful Villages in Italy, entering through the Porta di San Rocco next to the 15th-century chapel of the same name. The stone houses and cobblestone streets climbing to the hilltop have preserved the atmosphere of the past intact.

Admire Piazza Italia with the Casa dell'Orologio, a splendid example of Piedmontese Rococo style from the 16th century that once housed the Town Hall. Opposite stands Palazzo Borgese, in whose cellars you'll find La Bottega dei Quattro Vini for excellent wine tastings.

Visit the Archconfraternity of San Michele, a Baroque church from the second half of the 18th century designed by architect Antonio Borgese. Inside, noteworthy features include the Renaissance organ, a wooden statue of Archangel Michael, and a painting also dedicated to the Saint.

Explore the Parish Church of Saints Peter and Paul, dating from the 12th century but rebuilt in the 18th and expanded in the 19th. Inside you can appreciate numerous 18th-century works including statues, the altarpiece, and a precious inlaid choir.
Stroll through the historic center of Neive, among terracotta palaces, cobblestone streets and viewpoints over the Barbaresco and Moscato d'Asti vineyards.

activities.text: Stop at the Romano Levi Distillery to discover the legendary Grappa della Donna Selvatica, one of the most famous and prized labels in Italy. You can visit the distillery for free and purchase bottles with the iconic hand-painted labels.

visits.text: Take a motorboat to the Island of San Giulio, a vision of pure poetry floating on the lake waters. Legend has it that in the fourth century the Greek holy traveller Giulio drove out a serpent that ruled the island. Walk the Via del Silenzio, a ten-minute loop dotted with meditative signs inviting reflection and introspection.

Climb the Salita della Motta, a picturesque cobbled lane lined with frescoed houses leading to the Church of Santa Maria Assunta. From this elevated point you can admire one of the lake's most evocative panoramas, with the Island of San Giulio seemingly floating on the crystal-clear waters.

Visit the small Church of San Rocco on the main street, a hidden gem that wins you over with its welcoming and spiritual atmosphere. Beside it stands the Palazzo Comunale with its wonderful flower garden overlooking the lake, a corner of paradise in the heart of the village.

Explore the Sacro Monte di Orta, a UNESCO World Heritage Site rising on the hill above the village. This sixteenth- to seventeenth-century devotional complex comprises twenty frescoed chapels dedicated to the life of Saint Francis of Assisi, set in an ancient wood with spectacular views of the lake and island.
Route Stresa → Orta San Giulio (45 min)

activities.text: Wander through the cobbled lanes to Piazza Motta, the beating heart of the village overlooked by the sixteenth-century Palazzotto with its elegant arcades. From here public motorboats depart for the Island of San Giulio, offering unforgettable photographic vistas from the very moment of boarding.

Treat yourself to a lakeside stroll admiring the ancient frescoed palaces and breathing in the romantic atmosphere that also captivated Nietzsche, who arrived here almost by chance and was left spellbound by the beauty of the place. Villa Crespi, a Moorish-style masterpiece, is home to Antonino Cannavacciuolo's celebrated Michelin-starred restaurant.

visits.text: Discover Padova, one of Italy's oldest cities with legendary origins traced to the Trojan warrior Antenor. The UNESCO-listed Scrovegni Chapel houses Giotto's revolutionary 14th-century frescoes that changed Western art forever with their emotional realism and innovative use of color. Book your timed entry in advance for this artistic treasure.

Explore the Palazzo della Ragione, a vast medieval law court featuring one of the largest unsupported roofed halls in Europe, its walls covered with allegorical frescoes and celestial symbols. Below the arcades, discover Sotto il Salone - said to be Europe's oldest indoor food market where artisan shops have operated for generations.

Visit the Basilica of Saint Anthony (Il Santo), a major pilgrimage destination housing the saint's marble tomb and chapels frescoed by Giotto and other masters. The basilica combines Romanesque, Gothic, and Byzantine architectural elements into a unique synthesis of styles.

Stroll through Prato della Valle, one of Europe's largest squares, featuring the central Isola Memmia ringed by a canal and 78 statues of Padova's most illustrious figures. This grand public space transforms from market venue to evening promenade as locals gather.

activities.text: Experience the Padova Urbs Picta UNESCO trail connecting eight sites of 14th-century frescoes, including the glowing dome of paradise by Giusto de' Menabuoi in the Baptistery. The 48 or 72-hour card provides access to all sites.

Visit Palazzo del Bo, seat of the University of Padua founded in 1222, to see the Teatro Anatomico - the world's first permanent anatomy theatre - and Galileo's actual lecturing podium in guided tours of this historic academic institution.

Explore the Orto Botanico, the world's oldest university botanical garden still in its original location, a UNESCO World Heritage Site founded in 1545 with over 6,000 species including a palm tree planted in 1585 that inspired Goethe.

Stop at Caffè Pedrocchi, the legendary café open continuously from 1831 to 1916, where poets, professors, and revolutionaries gathered. The Sala Verde famously welcomed even those who couldn't afford coffee - giving rise to the Italian expression 'essere al verde' (to be broke).

Discover Parma, a sophisticated city in the heart of Emilia-Romagna renowned for its artistic heritage and culinary excellence. The historic center features the magnificent 12th-century Romanesque cathedral with its stunning frescoes by Correggio in the dome, and the adjacent octagonal Baptistery decorated with remarkable medieval sculptures and paintings.

Explore the Palazzo della Pilotta, a vast Renaissance complex housing the National Gallery with masterpieces by Correggio, Parmigianino, and other Italian masters. The palace also contains the Teatro Farnese, a remarkable wooden theatre built in 1618, and the Archaeological Museum displaying artifacts from the region's rich history.

activities.text: 'Food Valley' itinerary around Parma (stops at producers, farm shops)

Stroll through the elegant streets of the historic center, admiring the grand palazzos and charming piazzas that reflect Parma's aristocratic past. The city that gave birth to Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese and Prosciutto di Parma offers a perfect introduction to the treasures of its surrounding province.

visits.text: Explore the Fortress of Peschiera del Garda, an extraordinary example of military architecture enclosing the entire old town. Its walls, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2017, bear witness to centuries of history: from Roman fort to Scaliger stronghold, from sixteenth-century Venetian fortress to Habsburg citadel. Enter through the monumental Porta Verona or Porta Brescia to discover this defensive gem.

Visit the Sanctuary of the Madonna del Frassino, a splendid monumental church nestled in nature at the foot of the Lake Garda hills. Built between 1511 and 1514 on the spot where the Madonna appeared to the farmer Bartolomeo Broglia, the sanctuary kept by the Franciscan Friars Minor features a single nave and two marvellous frescoed chapels.

Discover Peschiera del Garda, where mighty star-shaped fortifications built by the Venetians form a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The historic fortress town guards the point where the Mincio River flows from Lake Garda, its massive walls and water-filled moats creating a dramatic defensive ensemble.

Explore the charming historic center within the fortifications, where canals, bridges, and Venetian architecture create an intimate lakeside atmosphere. The strategic importance of this location has been recognized since Roman times.

activities.text: Stroll along the Lungolago Mazzini, a wonderful lakeside promenade stretching about 700 metres from the old town to the Lido dei Cappuccini. This panoramic route, perfect at sunset, is lined with elegant establishments and offers spectacular views of the crystal-clear waters of Lake Garda.

Relax at the Lido Cappuccini, one of the lake's most popular bathing establishments where you can hire sun loungers and pedalos, swim in the clear waters and enjoy a refreshing break on the pebble beach, with lifeguard service and a restaurant right on the waterfront.

Use Peschiera as a base for visiting the nearby amusement parks including Gardaland, Italy's most popular theme park, Caneva Aquapark, and CanevaWorld Movieland. Shuttle buses connect the train station to these family-friendly attractions.

visits.text: Admire Piazza Cavalli, the beating heart of Piacenza dominated by two majestic Baroque equestrian statues of Alessandro and Ranuccio Farnese. Commissioned in 1600 and crafted by Mochi da Montevarchi over 13 years of work, they represent the third and fourth Duke of Parma and Piacenza in a breathtaking masterpiece of bronze casting.

Visit the Cathedral of Santa Maria Assunta and Santa Giustina, one of the best-preserved examples of Romanesque architecture in Italy. Built between the 11th and 12th centuries, it conceals behind its sober façade a richly frescoed interior, crowned by the extraordinary dome painted by Guercino in the 17th century. Climb the 136 steps to reach the 27-meter-high dome.

Explore the Museums of Palazzo Farnese, a sumptuous period building housing seven different exhibition areas: the Picture Gallery, the Carriage Museum, the Civic Museum, the Rizzi Vaccari Collection, the Ceramics Museum, the Risorgimento Museum, and the Archaeological Museum. A journey through centuries of Piacenza's history and art.

Discover the Ricci Oddi Modern Art Gallery, a museum established in 1931 that houses the famous Portrait of a Lady by Gustav Klimt. The painting, stolen in 1997 and found over twenty years later in a hidden trapdoor within the museum itself, has been visible again since 2020 and is one of the most mysterious masterpieces in art history.

activities.text: Stroll beneath the arcades of the historic center to the Basilica of Santa Maria di Campagna, a jewel of Renaissance art with its frescoed chapel blending religious and pagan figures. Since 2024, visitors can climb to the dome to admire the details of the masterpieces from a unique perspective.

Visit the Municipal Theater, inaugurated in the early 19th century and considered among the most beautiful in Italy, as Stendhal himself proclaimed. The three-quarter ellipse auditorium, revolutionary for its time, offers extraordinary acoustics and interior decorations of meticulous elegance.

visits.text: Experience the Pietra di Bismantova, a dramatic isolated rock formation rising from the Apennine foothills that inspired Dante's description of Purgatory in the Divine Comedy. This massive sandstone plateau, reaching 1,047 meters in altitude with sheer cliffs on all sides, creates one of the most distinctive natural landmarks in the entire region.

Explore the trails leading around and atop this remarkable geological formation, where centuries of erosion have sculpted the distinctive flat-topped profile. The hermitage of Santa Maria carved into the rock face adds spiritual significance to this already awe-inspiring natural monument.

activities.text: Hike to the summit plateau for panoramic views extending across the Apennines and toward the distant Po Valley. The Pietra di Bismantova offers climbing routes on its impressive cliff faces and easier walking paths that circle the base, making it accessible to visitors of all abilities.

visits.text: Explore the Grotte di Rescia, a fascinating system of natural cavities rich in stalactites and stalagmites bearing witness to millennia of geological activity. This underground spectacle offers a unique experience among limestone formations of bizarre and evocative shapes, wrapped in an atmosphere of mystery and natural wonder.

Visit the Church of San Vittore il Moro, the religious heart of the Porlezza community built in the seventeenth century over a pre-existing fifth-century structure. Inside you can admire the frescoes by Giulio Quaglio di Laino depicting episodes from the saint's life, a precious Baroque altar, eighteenth-century stuccowork and fine wooden sculptures.

Discover the Oratory of San Maurizio Martire, a small church set just outside the centre that still preserves its original layout. This gem of religious architecture is a precious testimony to local devotion through the centuries.

activities.text: Enjoy the Lombard shore of Lake Lugano, a body of water shared between Italy and Switzerland offering views of rare beauty. Porlezza is a renowned holiday resort prized for its crystal-clear waters, equipped beaches and relaxed atmosphere that draws visitors from all over Europe.

visits.text: Discover Rovigo, a provincial capital often overlooked in favor of Venice and Verona but rich with unexpected treasures. Torre Donà, at 66 meters, remains one of Italy's tallest medieval brick towers - a remnant of the city's 10th-century castle that once dominated the landscape.

Visit La Rotonda (Church of Madonna del Soccorso), designed by a pupil of Palladio to house a miraculous image of the Madonna. The church's entire interior is covered with remarkable 17th-century frescoes creating an immersive artistic experience.

Explore the Pinacoteca dei Concordi in the Renaissance Palazzo Roverella, housing originals by Tiepolo, Giovanni Bellini, and Palma the Elder. The archaeological collection and temporary exhibitions add depth to this cultural visit.

visits.text: Explore the medieval historic center of Saluzzo, one of the best preserved in Italy, dominated by Monviso. The former capital of the Marquisate, this town was the birthplace of illustrious figures such as Silvio Pellico, General Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa, and typographer Giambattista Bodoni, inventor of the famous typeface.

Visit La Castiglia, the Marquis's fortress built in 1200 with four towers, bastions, drawbridge, and moat. After serving as a prison in the 19th century, it now houses the city museums and offers panoramic views over the plain and the Alps.

Admire the Church of San Giovanni, one of the oldest in Saluzzo dating from the late 1200s, the former seat of the Dominicans. Notable is the funerary chapel of the marquises in the apse, while in the cloister you'll find the wonderful Cappella Cavassa with Renaissance frescoes.

Climb the Civic Tower of the Ancient Palazzo Comunale to enjoy an exceptional panorama from the plain to the Alps. Inside the palace, you can visit the Hall of Congregations with its coffered ceiling from the 1400s and the Picture Gallery dedicated to Occitan painter Matteo Olivero.

activities.text: Stroll through the Porti Scur, the characteristic low arcades where light barely filters through and where the traditional Marcà d'le fomne market is held, where hillside peasant women sell their seasonal produce.

Visit the House-Museum of Silvio Pellico in the piazzetta dei Mondagli, where the author of My Prisons was born on June 25, 1789. A dive into Italian Risorgimento history in a building that preserves relics and documents of the patriot writer.

visits.text: Admire the Scaliger Castle, a majestic medieval fortress built after the mid-fourteenth century standing at the entrance to the old town. Surrounded by the crystal-clear waters of Lake Garda, the castle with its dock, courtyard and corridors evokes the poignant atmosphere of the Della Scala era, when it served as a strategic defensive position for the entire area.

Explore the Grotte di Catullo, the evocative remains of an ancient Roman villa from the first to second century AD in a spectacular position at the tip of the peninsula. Set among ancient olive trees and overlooking the lake panorama, the ruins are linked by popular tradition to the poet Catullus. The adjacent museum houses precious artefacts from Sirmione's and Lake Garda's history.

Visit the Church of San Pietro in Mavino, the oldest in the area dating from the eighth century AD. Nestled among olive trees on the hill of the same name, it offers an atmosphere of peace and silence with its Romanesque bell tower renovated in 1070 and evocative fourteenth-century frescoes, including a fine Madonna Enthroned with Child and Saints.

Discover the Palazzo Callas Exhibitions, dedicated to the memory of the Divine Maria Callas who chose Sirmione as her Italian refuge. Follow the evocative Callas Arie On Air trail, which through ten stops at the peninsula's most characteristic locations lets you relive the unique atmosphere of the most beautiful arias performed by the celebrated soprano.
Discovery of Pisogne and the church of Santa Maria della Neve decorated with 15th century frescoes
Boat crossing to Monte Isola and visit to a fishing village

Discover Sirmione, dramatically positioned on a narrow peninsula extending into Lake Garda. The Scaliger Castle rises directly from the water, its crenellated towers and enclosed harbor creating one of Italy's most romantic castle settings.

Explore the Grottoes of Catullus (Grotte di Catullo), the atmospheric ruins of a vast Roman villa at the peninsula's tip. These are the largest and best-preserved Roman villa remains in Northern Italy, with olive groves, lake views, and an on-site museum.

activities.text: Relax at Spiaggia Giamaica, an exotic-feeling spot at the tip of Sirmione below the Grotte di Catullo. Formed of smooth white rocks polished by the waves, surrounded by crystal-clear waters and wild vegetation, it offers spectacular views towards the Rocca di Manerba and the northern part of the lake.

Treat yourself to a boat trip around the Sirmione peninsula to admire the harbour, Scaliger Castle, the Grotte di Catullo, the thermal facilities and Villa Callas from a unique perspective, interspersed with wonderful natural panoramas and lush Mediterranean vegetation.

Stroll through the old village from the Scaliger Castle to the Grotte di Catullo, immersing yourself in local history through evocative lanes, the remains of the Church of San Salvatore and Roman-era sites, with refreshing stops in the parks and characteristic establishments of the old town.
Cruise between Sulzano and Monte Isola on Lake Iseo

Experience Sirmione's thermal spas, where hot sulfurous waters have attracted visitors since Roman times. Boat trips around the promontory offer perspectives on the castle, villas, and the crystal-clear waters of Lake Garda.

visits.text: Marvel at Villa Pisani, lauded as the Queen of the Venetian Villas, a palatial estate as grand as a royal residence. This magnificent 18th-century villa features fully frescoed rooms including Tiepolo's stunning ceiling masterpiece, a lush garden with an intricate hedge maze, and fascinating historical connections to Napoleon.

Visit the adjacent Villa Foscarini Rossi, home to a unique Shoe Museum displaying hundreds of examples of Italian footwear craftsmanship. The elegant villa provides insight into the refined lifestyle of Venetian nobility along the Brenta Riviera.

activities.text: Explore the extensive gardens of Villa Pisani, featuring formal parterres, ornamental ponds, and the famous labyrinth. The grounds offer a perfect setting for a leisurely stroll through centuries of landscape design.

visits.text: Explore Isola Bella, the jewel of the Borromean Islands housing the splendid Palazzo Borromeo, a perfectly preserved noble residence with precious paintings, tapestries and antique furnishings. The magnificent Borromean Gardens, created in the seventeenth century in pure Italian Baroque style, cascade over ten terraces towards the lake with an extraordinary variety of floral species and monumental statues.

Visit Isola Madre, the largest and most evocative of the Borromean Islands, wrapped in a quiet, suspended atmosphere. The sixteenth-century palace houses vast collections of period objects and a curious display of historic puppets, while the lush botanical garden is celebrated for its magnificent camellias, azaleas and exotic plants.

Admire Villa Pallavicino, an elegant nineteenth-century residence surrounded by a vast English-style garden hosting a fascinating zoological park. Among magnificent avenues lined with ancient trees and a wonderful botanical garden, you can encounter kangaroos, fallow deer, zebras and llamas in a beautifully kept natural setting, ideal for families with children.

Discover the Church of Sant'Ambrogio in the heart of Stresa, an elegant example of Neoclassical architecture with a Greek-cross plan completed in 1790. Inside lie the relics of San Vitaliano, a young Christian martyr venerated as protector of children, whose cult was introduced in 1835 following the transfer of his remains from the Roman catacombs.

visits.text: Be enchanted by the Mole Antonelliana, the iconic symbol of Turin that towers over the rooftops of the historic center with its 170-meter height. Designed by architect Alessandro Antonelli as a synagogue, it now houses the National Museum of Cinema, one of the most important in the world. Take the spectacular panoramic elevator to the dome and enjoy breathtaking views of the city and the Alps.

Explore the Egyptian Museum, Turin's most important cultural gem and one of the richest Egyptian collections in the world, second only to Cairo's. Among mummies, sarcophagi, papyri, and monumental statues, you'll experience a fascinating journey through the civilization of the pharaohs via artifacts of inestimable historical and artistic value.

Admire the Chapel of the Holy Shroud, a Baroque masterpiece designed by Guarino Guarini and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, which houses the sacred cloth bearing the image that Christians identify as the deposed Christ. The black marble architecture and spiral dome represent an absolute pinnacle of Italian creative genius.

Stroll beneath the 18 kilometers of arcades that form a great pedestrian ring connecting the city's main squares. From Piazza San Carlo, nicknamed Turin's drawing room, to Piazza Castello with the Royal Palace and Teatro Regio, you'll discover the Baroque and Neoclassical elegance of Italy's first capital.

activities.text: Treat yourself to a break in one of Turin's historic cafés, temples of taste where the bicerin was born and where the famous gianduiotti chocolates have been made since 1852. Establishments like Caffè Fiorio, Caffè San Carlo, or Caffè Mulassano have preserved their Belle Époque décor and old-world atmosphere intact.

Visit the Reggia di Venaria, a UNESCO World Heritage royal residence located just 10 km from the center, featuring frescoes, sculptures, original furnishings, and lush gardens. Once the Savoy family's summer residence for hunting expeditions, it's an Italian version of the Palace of Versailles.

days_plan.itin_title: Piedmont Wine & Truffle Road Trip: Turin, Alba & Barolo in 9 Days

visits.text: Marvel at the Castle of Torrechiara, one of the most beautiful and best-preserved castles in Italy, rising majestically above the Parma hills. Built in the 15th century by Pier Maria Rossi for his beloved mistress Bianca Pellegrini, the fortress combines military strength with Renaissance elegance, its four corner towers connected by crenellated walls creating a fairytale silhouette against the sky.

Explore the castle's famous Camera d'Oro (Golden Chamber), decorated with frescoes depicting the love story of Pier Maria and Bianca, making this fortress a rare example of a castle built for love rather than war. The interior preserves remarkable Renaissance decorations while the exterior walls have defended the hilltop for over five centuries.

activities.text: Admire the castle illuminated at night, when carefully placed lighting transforms this romantic fortress into a magical spectacle visible from the valley below. The strategic position on the road to the mountains makes Torrechiara the perfect castle to visit when combining a mountain excursion with cultural heritage.

visits.text: Explore Treviso, the birthplace of tiramisu, radicchio rosso, and prosecco - three delights that make life more delicious. This beautiful Northern Italian city features breathtaking frescoed buildings, mighty defensive walls, and narrow curving streets often overlooked by travelers heading straight to Venice.

Visit the Church of St. Francis (Chiesa di San Francesco), a late Romanesque/early Gothic masterpiece with important 13th-century frescoes. Inside are the tombs of Petrarch's daughter Francesca and Dante's son Pietro - remarkable literary connections.

Discover Piazza dei Signori, the main square surrounded by Palazzo del Podesta with its 13th-century Civic Tower, the Gothic Palazzo dei Trecento, and Palazzo Pretorio. The Loggia dei Cavalieri, a 13th-century structure with faded frescoes, served nobility for meetings and games.

activities.text: Explore La Pescheria, a small island where the fresh fish market has operated for centuries, and the Church of San Nicolo for its frescoes including the earliest known depiction of spectacles in Europe.
Visit the Duomo San Pietro, Treviso's seven-domed cathedral housing a Titian and an atmospheric crypt, plus the Civic Museums of Santa Caterina and Luigi Bailo for fine art and exhibitions.

visits.text: Continue through Prosecco Country to Valdobbiadene, at the heart of the production zone for the finest DOCG sparkling wines. The steep hillsides, many cultivated by hand, produce grapes of exceptional quality that have made this region world-famous.

Explore the charming town and surrounding hamlets where winemaking traditions have been passed down through generations. The landscape of terraced vineyards cascading down precipitous slopes is a testament to centuries of viticultural dedication.

activities.text: Enjoy stunning hiking through the vine-covered hills, stopping at small wineries along the way. The combination of natural beauty, traditional agriculture, and excellent wine makes this region a paradise for wine lovers and outdoor enthusiasts alike.
