visits.text: Valsesia – discovery of the Sesia valley, hillside vineyards and suspended hamlets
Varallo – Sacro Monte (UNESCO heritage) and historic center

Climb to the Sacro Monte di Varallo, the oldest and most spectacular in Italy, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2003. Founded in 1491 by Franciscan friar Bernardino Caimi upon his return from the Holy Land, he wanted to recreate in Valsesia the sacred places of Palestine for pilgrims who couldn't reach Jerusalem.

Explore the 45 chapels scattered through the greenery containing over 800 life-size polychrome terracotta statues and about 4,000 frescoed figures. The theatrical effects, such as real hair and beards applied to 500-year-old statues, are truly breathtaking.

Visit the Basilica dedicated to the Virgin Mary Assumed, built in the 19th century at the summit of the Sacro Monte. The square in front, with its numerous chapels, porticoes, fountain, and palm trees, offers a striking visual effect and mystical atmosphere.

activities.text: Whitewater on the Sesia torrent: rafting/kayak (supervised sports course)
Canyoning in a secure tributary of the valley (beginner to intermediate level)
No-kill sport fishing on authorized reaches (permit required)

Ascend to the Sacro Monte via the cable car reopened in 2003, which departs from the center of Varallo and reaches the summit in just minutes while hugging a rocky cliff. The large windows of the cabin offer spectacular views of the Valsesia valley.

Descend on foot through the evocative forest path that returns you to Varallo in about 20 minutes. The wide, paved trail passes through a natural environment of great beauty, part of the Special Nature Reserve of the Piedmont Region.

days_plan.itin_title: Piedmont Valleys, Italy: Mountain Sports and Nature Preserves
Piedmont Wine & Truffle Road Trip: Turin, Alba & Barolo in 9 Days

visits.text: Visit the Castle of Varano de' Melegari, a fortress of significant importance in the regional history of the Parma province. This medieval stronghold, strategically positioned at the entrance to the Ceno Valley, played a crucial role in controlling the mountain passes and trade routes through the Apennines for centuries.

Explore the village nestled below the castle walls, where traditional stone architecture reflects centuries of mountain community life. The settlement marks the gateway to the more dramatic castle landscapes of the upper valleys, serving as a perfect transition point between the plains and the Apennine mountains.

activities.text: Take in views of the surrounding valley from the castle grounds, where the landscape begins its dramatic rise toward the Apennine peaks. The area offers the first taste of the mountain scenery that characterizes the famous castles further up the valley.

days_plan.itin_title: Emilia-Romagna's Hidden Treasures: Castles, Apennines & the Great Labyrinth

visits.text: Admire the Church of San Giorgio, a splendid example of thirteenth-century medieval Lombard architecture built on the foundations of an ancient Roman temple. The grey stone façade is dominated by a majestic bell tower, while inside the 1822 Baroque high altar and a precious cycle of frescoes stand out. The floor of fine black marble completes the elegance of this sacred place.

Explore Villa Monastero, an evocative sixteenth-century architectural complex that was once a Cistercian convent. Today it is one of the lake's main attractions with its house museum and extraordinary botanical gardens hosting hundreds of plant species from around the world, along a path winding beside the lakeshore.

Visit Villa Cipressi, an elegant late-Renaissance gem with terraces cascading down towards the lake. This historic complex offers romantic views and manicured gardens delivering unforgettable panoramas over the waters of the Lario and the surrounding mountains.
Stroll through the historic center of Varenna and along the lakeside promenade
Visit to Villa Monastero and its terraced botanical gardens

activities.text: Walk the Passeggiata degli Innamorati (Lovers' Walk), a romantic walkway of about 500 metres suspended on the cliff face above the lake. This arched structure, draped in climbing plants that burst into a riot of colour and fragrance in the warmer months, connects the landing stage to the colourful houses of the old town in a route of incomparable beauty.

Climb to the Castello di Vezio, an ancient fortress overlooking Varenna from above with spectacular views of the lake and surrounding villages. You can explore the gardens, the atmospheric underground passages and the square watchtower housing a permanent art exhibition.
Free time to enjoy the lakeside cafés and small squares of Varenna

visits.text: Guided tour of Treviso's historic center: Piazza dei Signori and picturesque canals

Experience Venice, the incomparable city built on 118 islands connected by 400 bridges over 150 canals. Take vaporetto line 1 down the Grand Canal to witness architectural masterpieces including Ca' Pesaro, Ca' d'Oro, Rialto Bridge, and the Basilica Santa Maria della Salute - a floating introduction to La Serenissima's unparalleled beauty.

Visit the Doge's Palace, the magnificent Gothic masterpiece that was the seat of Venetian government for centuries. Explore the ornate chambers, cross the Bridge of Sighs, and discover how this maritime republic became one of history's most powerful and wealthy states.

Discover St. Mark's Basilica, the glittering Byzantine cathedral crowned with golden mosaics covering over 8,000 square meters. Climb the Campanile for panoramic views across the lagoon to the distant Alps on clear days.

Explore the Arsenal, once the world's largest industrial complex where the Republic built its powerful naval fleet. The Ships' Pavilion displays historic vessels while the massive gates and towers testify to Venice's maritime supremacy.

activities.text: Wander through the fresh produce and fish markets at Rialto, where vendors have sold the lagoon's bounty for over ten centuries. Cross the canal on a traghetto - the traditional gondola ferry that locals use daily.

Sample cicchetti - Venice's traditional savory snacks - at bacari (wine bars) washed down with an ombra (small glass of wine). This Venetian tradition offers an authentic taste of local culinary culture.
Discover the Fondazione Querini Stampalia, an off-the-beaten-track palace museum with stunning art collections and a beautiful garden designed by Carlo Scarpa. A perfect escape from the crowds.

days_plan.itin_title: Friuli's Hidden Corners: Cividale, Palmanova & The Carnic Alps

visits.text: Lose yourself in the magnificent Botanical Gardens of Villa Taranto, twenty hectares of pure wonder on the shores of Lake Maggiore. Created by Scottish Captain McEacharn from 1931, these enchanting English-style gardens feature labyrinths of dahlias, water lily pools, valleys of rhododendrons, waterfalls and fountains in a place where care and love for nature are palpable at every turn.

Visit Villa San Remigio on the Colle della Castagnola, built in the early twentieth century by the poet and musician Marquis Silvio della Valle di Casanova and the painter Sofia Browne. Their dream garden is a true hymn to love, composed of several themed gardens overlooking the lake in a romantic atmosphere suspended in time.

Discover Villa Giulia and its park in the heart of Pallanza, built in the mid-nineteenth century by the Branca family, inventors of the famous Fernet. Now municipal property, it hosts temporary exhibitions while the park, always open and free, offers a privileged view of the lake and the picturesque village of Pallanza.

activities.text: Walk the lakeside promenade from Verbania to Pallanza, a pedestrian and cycle path of about 2 km offering breathtaking panoramas, ancient villas and dream palaces. An itinerary for daydreaming of a less hectic life on the lakefront, imagining yourself in an age of noble titles and grand balls.

Venture along the path to the Church of Buon Rimedio, an ancient mule track through jasmine-scented woods to a small eighteenth-century church. From this natural balcony overlooking Lake Maggiore you can enjoy breathtaking panoramic views and picnic at the equipped area with lakeside tables.

Explore the historic village of Pallanza with the Museo del Paesaggio housed in the Palazzo Viani Dugnani, rich in paintings, sculptures and archaeological finds. Then treat yourself to a stop at one of the lakeside terraces on the main square to savour the relaxed atmosphere of this enchanting corner of Piedmont.

days_plan.itin_title: Ciociaria Itinerary: Abbeys and Medieval Mountain Villages

visits.text: Let yourself be enchanted by the Arena di Verona, a majestic Roman amphitheatre built in 30 AD and splendidly preserved. Originally capable of seating up to 30,000 spectators, today it is one of the world's most prestigious venues for open-air opera and concerts, where the perfect acoustics and magical atmosphere make every performance unforgettable.

Visit Juliet's House on Via Cappello, the iconic symbol of Shakespearean romance with its famous balcony and courtyard that have inspired the timeless love story. In the courtyard you can admire the bronze statue of Juliet by Nereo Costantini, which tradition says brings luck in love to those who touch it.

Explore Castelvecchio and the Ponte Scaligero, an imposing medieval fortress with a magnificent fortified bridge offering breathtaking views over the River Adige. The museum inside houses extraordinary collections of medieval and Renaissance art, sculptures, paintings and the city's ancient bells displayed across 29 unique rooms.

Admire the Basilica of San Zeno Maggiore, a masterpiece of Romanesque architecture built between 967 and 1398 AD. The intricate bronze doors, extraordinary frescoes and imposing altarpiece by Mantegna will take your breath away. According to tradition, the crypt is the place where Romeo and Juliet celebrated their secret marriage.

Discover the Roman Theatre, an ancient first-century BC theatre rising on a hill overlooking the city and the River Adige. In summer it hosts the Estate Teatrale Veronese with performances of drama, dance and music in a unique atmosphere where history and culture blend under the stars.
Exploration of Verona's Roman amphitheater, the Arena, still active for operas.
Stop by Casa di Giulietta and its famous balcony.
Discovery of Piazza delle Erbe and the surrounding shopping streets.

Discover Fair Verona, the city forever linked with Romeo and Juliet. The Arena di Verona in Piazza Bra, a remarkably preserved Roman amphitheatre that predates Rome's Colosseum by a century, now hosts one of the world's most spectacular opera festivals under the stars.

Wander Piazza delle Erbe and Piazza dei Signori, medieval squares lined with beautifully frescoed buildings, the elegant Palazzo Maffei, and the Madonna Verona fountain - the recognized symbol of the city. The statue of Dante marks the square's heart.

Visit Juliet's House with its famous balcony (actually a repurposed sarcophagus). Tour the interior for a fascinating look at 13th-century life, and perhaps leave a letter at Juliet's Club where the 'Secretaries of Juliet' respond to lovesick correspondents worldwide.
Explore Castelvecchio, the medieval castle now housing a splendid art collection. Cross the dramatic Scaliger Bridge with its distinctive swallowtail battlements spanning the Adige River.

activities.text: Stroll through Piazza delle Erbe, the beating heart of Verona surrounded by colourful buildings, frescoed palaces and lively market stalls. At the centre of the square stands the fountain of Madonna Verona, while all around you can breathe the vibrant atmosphere of a city that has preserved its charm through the centuries.

Lose yourself in the Giardino Giusti, one of the finest Italian-style gardens in existence, with geometric flowerbeds, ancient cypresses, grottoes and panoramic terraces offering breathtaking views across all of Verona. This sixteenth-century Renaissance gem is the perfect spot for a refreshing pause immersed in beauty.

Cross the Ponte Pietra, the ancient Roman bridge linking the old town to the bohemian quarter of Veronetta. From here you'll enjoy enchanting views of the River Adige, the Roman Theatre and the hill of San Pietro, the perfect setting for a sunset stroll.
Ice cream or granita break on Piazza delle Erbe and sunset walk.
Climb Torre dei Lamberti, built in 1172 and Verona's tallest tower, for inspiring views over the red rooftops of the historic center to the surrounding hills and distant Alps.
Visit the Roman Theatre and Archaeological Museum on the hillside, still used for performances, and the nearby Giardino Giusti - a Renaissance garden offering stunning panoramic views over Verona.
Try the local sweets Baci di Romeo and Baci di Giulietta (Romeo's and Juliet's Kisses) - delicious confections of almond paste with buttercream or hazelnut paste with chocolate cream.

days_plan.itin_title: Rome, Italy: Colosseum, Vatican and Ancient City Wonders

visits.text: Explore Vicenza, the City of Palladio and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, where streets are lined with palaces by the most influential architect of the past 500 years. Andrea Palladio used Vicenza as his personal architectural playground, creating designs that inspired buildings from St. Petersburg to Washington.

Visit the Basilica Palladiana, the stunning centerpiece of Piazza dei Signori and the jewel in Palladio's crown. The rooftop terrace offers unparalleled views over the city, while temporary art exhibitions of international caliber are held within.

Experience Teatro Olimpico, the first indoor masonry theatre in the world, featuring the oldest surviving stage set still in use today. Palladio's final masterpiece creates the illusion of infinite perspective through its remarkable permanent scenery.

Discover the Church of Santa Corona, built in 1261 to house a Holy Thorn from Christ's Crown. The church contains paintings by Giovanni Bellini and Paolo Veronese, plus access to the nearby Diocesan Museum where the precious relic is now kept.
Teatro Olimpico - oldest covered masonry theater in the world with famous Renaissance stage trompe-l'oeil, UNESCO World Heritage Site
Basilica Palladiana - palace of Reason built by Palladio in 1546 on Piazza dei Signori, masterpiece of Renaissance architecture
Palazzo Chiericati - palace built by Palladio in 1550, major example of Palladian architecture on Piazza Matteotti
Tempio di San Lorenzo - Gothic church along Corso Palladio
Villa Rotonda - famous Palladian villa with central plan and dome, located at the city gates, UNESCO World Heritage listed
Villa Valmarana Ai Nani - villa at the gates of Vicenza famous for its fresco cycle by Giambattista Tiepolo and his son Giandomenico
Palazzo Porto - unfinished work by Palladio on Piazza Castello, UNESCO World Heritage listed

activities.text: Visit the Jewellery Museum, the first in Italy, reflecting Vicenza's importance as one of Italy's major centers of jewellery making. Elegant shops throughout the city display the continuing vitality of this creative tradition.

Explore the Civic Art Gallery of Palazzo Chiericati, a stunning Palladian palace housing collections spanning the 13th to 20th centuries. The Palladio Museum offers models and exhibits explaining the architect's revolutionary techniques.
Giardini Salvi - historic gardens 500 meters from the station, ideal starting point to discover the city
Corso Palladio - main artery of the historic center lined with Renaissance palaces and monuments
Ponte di San Michele - picturesque bridge built between 1621 and 1623 spanning the Retrone river
Parco Querini - vast secular park in the heart of the city with lakes, canals, hills and tempietti
Visit to artisan workshops - discovery of ancient lithography and art printing techniques in the botteghe of the center
Colli Berici - hills south of Vicenza offering natural landscapes, cycling paths and gastronomic sagre throughout the year

visits.text: Explore the fortified village of Vigoleno, certified among the Most Beautiful Villages in Italy and Orange Flag of the Italian Touring Club. This perfect example of medieval residential logic is characterized by the elegance of its forms, with imposing crenellated walls traversed by a panoramic patrol walkway.

Climb the quadrangular keep equipped with arrow slits, machicolations, and Ghibelline merlons, with four floors of visits offering spectacular views over the surrounding countryside and hills. Inside the castle, the small theater with oriental images is a hidden gem not to be missed.

Visit the Romanesque Church of San Giorgio from the second half of the 12th century, reachable by continuing east from the main square where the 16th-century fountain stands. The intimate and spiritual atmosphere of this sacred place transports you back in time.

Step into the medieval village of Vigoleno, a perfectly preserved walled borgo listed among Italy's most beautiful villages. Enclosed within intact 14th-century walls, this tiny hamlet contains just a handful of buildings including a Romanesque church, a castle, and stone houses that create an intimate glimpse into medieval Italian life.

Visit the Castle of Vigoleno, whose towers and ramparts have guarded this hilltop settlement since the 12th century. The fortress offers commanding views over the Arda Valley and surrounding countryside, while the village's complete medieval integrity makes it feel like a living museum of medieval architecture.

activities.text: Taste the Vin Santo di Vigoleno, a DOC passito wine whose vinification and aging operations must be carried out exclusively in the territory of the municipality of Vernasca. A golden nectar representing the oenological excellence of the Piacenza Hills.

Walk the Brigands' Ring, a circuit of about 21 km that starts from Vigoleno and arrives in Vernasca passing through Monte Ciocca. During flowering season, the golden broom creates an unforgettable natural spectacle.

Explore the village's narrow lanes and discover the small Romanesque oratory with its ancient frescoes. The entire settlement can be explored in an hour, but its atmospheric charm and historical authenticity make it an essential stop on any castle route through the Parma province.

visits.text: Marvel at Villa Capra 'La Rotonda', Palladio's most famous villa and one of the most copied buildings in the world. Its perfectly symmetrical design, with identical temple-front porticos on all four sides, inspired countless buildings including the White House in Washington D.C.

Visit Villa Valmarana ai Nani, named for the stone dwarf statues lining its walls, featuring interior frescoes by father and son Tiepolo that rank among their finest work. The splendid garden and café overlooking Mount Berico provide a perfect setting for reflection.

activities.text: Walk between the two villas through the gentle countryside of Vicenza's outskirts, enjoying views of Mount Berico and the Church of St. Mary of Mount Berico overlooking the city from its hilltop position.

visits.text: Step into Serravalle (now part of Vittorio Veneto), a medieval fairytale town that ranks among the most picturesque in Italy. Cobbled streets, stone houses with frescoed facades, and an ancient castle create an atmospheric setting that transports visitors centuries back in time.

Visit the Museo del Cenedese for fabulous frescoes, paintings, and works of art, including access to a fully frescoed chapel where babies born in the local hospital were once baptized. The artistic heritage here rivals better-known destinations.

activities.text: Wander the medieval streets photographing the unique architecture and peaceful squares. Unlike more touristy medieval towns, Serravalle offers authentic atmosphere without crowds.
